data: Ecclesall C of E Junior School

Ecclesall C of E Junior School is situated in a suburban area of Sheffield although it has a large proportion of pupils from outside the immediate area. 

A quarter of the school population is drawn from a wide range of minority ethnic backgrounds. Three-quarters of the pupils are of White British heritage. Low numbers of pupils are eligible for Pupil Premium or Pupil Premium Plus funding. 

The proportion of children with special educational needs, including those with a statement/EHCP of special educational needs, is above average.

Ecclesall Junior School has been teaching French (Upper Key Stage 2) since we took part in the Sheffield Pathfinder Project in 2003.

Initially, French was taught by a specialist language teacher, however, in order to increase the pupil’s exposure to the French language we decided that class teachers would take over the role of teaching French.

This decision highlighted several issues with language learning in our school.

A high proportion of staff don’t have the confidence and language competence to deliver French adequately. As a result, they are nervous to teach French and it is not taught consistently across all year groups. To encourage staff to be more involved in language learning, we would like them to have the opportunity to improve their language skills and develop new teaching methods, sharing resources and ideas.

Eccleshall Infant and Junior School will merge in September 2018.  We will then consolidate how we teach French across the new larger school. 

It will take some time to integrate the two schools. Making use of the changes caused by this merger we will send staff from both schools on a structured training so that all year groups are fully equipped with the training, knowledge and resources they require to fully integrate language learning into the curriculum of the newly combined school.

This project is very much linked to our School Development Plan and is supported by our SLT and Governors. It will greatly influence the development of our school in relation to the learning of languages.

We have staff of varying abilities in the school, a situation which will be exacerbated when our schools merge in September this year. In this context, this project presents a fantastic opportunity to take steps towards levelling the French skill set across the school and we expect that, by bringing teachers from both schools together it will also contribute to the process of developing the two schools into a single teaching organisation.

Our  project will result in us having greater capacity within our school to teach languages in more Key stages. Teachers and support staff will expand their skills base and become more flexible in what they can offer. 

Improvements in learning and teaching methodology, new ideas shared with the link school, a variety of engaging resources and direct communication with native speakers will make our teaching more enjoyable, and pupils far more engaged and motivated to learn languages. 

By improving the provision of French in KS2 and introducing it in KS1, attainment will be much greater and pupils will be far better equipped with language skills on entering secondary school.
Ecclesall C of E Junior School
PATHS: for Solidarity Economy and Youth Entrepreneurship in Europe

PATHS: Youth for Solidarity Economy and Entrepreneurship in Europe (PATHS) is a strategic partnership between European organizations active in the field of education, training and youth designed to promote cooperation and innovation in the field of young social entrepreneurship. 

This project arises from the analysis of the context in which organizations develop their activities and their previous experience in this field. The outcomes of this analysis are: 

1. Given the difficulties that young people find their access to the labour market, youth entrepreneurship is an alternative to unemployment. 

2. To become an entrepreneur is not necessary a specific qualification or a particular academic level, but many young companies die in the first two years. That means that could be necessary to improve the qualifications of young entrepreneurs to reduce the high mortality of young companies. 

3. Entrepreneurship projects based approaches solidarity economy have a mortality rate significantly lower than the entrepreneurial projects of competitive basis. 

4. Organizations in the field of non-formal education and academic institutions (formal education) have interest in promoting entrepreneurship among young people. But there are not enough methodological and training tools. 

5. Given the current social context of Europe and the future prospects, young entrepreneurship will not be a fad. Instead could be the only chance for a new generation. 

The project objectives are: 

1. To promote cooperation and networking among participating organizations, developing a line of work maintained over time (integral promotion of youth entrepreneurship) based on the ongoing collaboration between European organizations (strategic alliance). 

2. To increase the capacity of organizations working on the promotion of youth entrepreneurship through resources, materials and tools that will improve the quality of its activities and the results thereof. 

3. To promote the development of specific skills by workers of the organizations involved (trainers, trainers, youth workers) and to promote their professional training as facilitators of youth entrepreneurship projects in the field of solidarity economy. 

4. To contribute to the promotion of entrepreneurship among young people as an alternative to unemployment and, simultaneously, as a way to emancipation and to contribute to society. 

5. To contribute to strengthening youth entrepreneurship projects and its transformation into solidarity economy enterprises with consequent multiplier effect in terms of employment and contribution to the common welfare. 

6. Contribute to the normalization of entrepreneurship training approaches combining formal and non-formal education to the specific needs of the business world. 

The Partners that are involved in the project are: Red Internacional B-Live (Spain), Universidad de Coimbra (Portugal), Association des Agences de la Democratie Locale (France). Citizens in Action (Greece) y Youth Discovery Ventures Ltd (UK). 

The project duration is 14 months (February 2015 - March 2016) and it includes tree intellectual outputs:

- Mapping of solidarity entrepreneurship in Europe. Comprehensive overview of existing resources at the European level and in each of the countries of the participating organizations, useful for energizing entrepreneurship solidarity projects.

- Curriculum for training facilitators of entrepreneurship solidarity projects. The curriculum will have an European dimension and a clear focus on practical learning through non-formal education.

- Collection of non-formal education training resources for facilitators of youth entrepreneurship projects in the field of solidarity economy. 90 training materials divided into 40 activities, 20 dynamics, and 30 additional training resources, all of them based on non-formal education methods.

The project also includes five multiplier events and a training course for 15 european workers in the field of youth, for training as facilitators of young entrepreneurship projects in the field of solidarity economy.

Strategic partnership project KA2 “Include! Involve! Improve!” is a partnership between 10 organizations from Estonia, Portugal, Spain, Italy, Greece, Romania, Poland, UK, Slovakia and Turkey and will last from 1st September 2016 to 31st August  2018. Project will have 4 transnational project meetings which will involve 44 participants from 10 partner countries, 3 short-term joint staff training events, which will train total of 78 youth workers from 10 countries and 2 long-term mobilities of youth workers, where 10 youth workers from Spain, Portugal, Greece, Italy and Estonia will practice youth work in Estonia, Spain and Portugal.  Additionally we will carry out local activities every month in Estonia and in partner countries. The general aim of our project is to raise the quality of international youth project via exchange of good practices between the network of strategic partners. Concrete objectives are:- To raise the quality of Erasmus + projects in the field of youth inside and outside partner network- To ensure quality preparation and support for Estonian young people and youth workers before they attend international event- To train youth leaders to raise their competence as group leaders in international youth projects- To spread the information about Erasmus + projects to a wider audience with focus on involving more young people with fewer opportunities in international projects through engaging local youth workers- Exchange good practices in local and international youth work between partners to raise the quality of youth exchanges- To build up a solid network of partners to organize youth projects which are inclusive, support participation of young people with fewer opportunities and take into account human rights and democratic valuesAll our methods we plan to use are based on non-formal learning. Trainings and transnational meetings are based on the same idea, and we do include moderators and trainers who are familiar with non-formal learning methods and can also provide some input. We will use methods such as discussions, analyses, role-plays, group building exercises, creative tools, study visits, activities with local communities etc. We want that our activities are an example of non-formal learning in international context, and besides providing space to share and learn from each other and gain new competences, we want to make our activities/mobilities as a good example, from which to learn also.Some of the expected results include: - 44 participants have taken part of joint staff meetings over 2 years and contributed to the exchange of good practices between partner organizations- We have trained 78 youth workers via 3 short-term trainings for staff and they have gained specific competences to raise the quality of youth work in all participating countries- We have engaged directly 10 000 young people/youth workers in various local activities. At least 3000 participants have be involved in Estonia and rest in partner countries. At least 50 % of target group reached has been with fewer opportunities (5000 people). - 10 youth workers from Estonia, Spain, Portugal, Italy and Greece have taken part of the long-term mobility of youth workers and learned and shared good practices.  - We will have created at least 3 manuals directed to youth workers and organizations, young people and group leaders in youth exchanges.

Sustainable Living Lab is an experiential learning project which immerses participants in a multi-cultural environment focused on living in community, daily yoga and meditation, performing practical tasks associated with living sustainably, and serving the wider community.  

The project is located at Ananda Gaorii Ashram, Farm and Learning Center, a 13 hectare organic farm and seminar facility in the Danish countryside about an hour from Copenhagen. Ananda Gaorii normally has around 20 to 30 residents, including staff, guests and volunteers from Europe and other countries. Ananda Gaorii hosts regular workshops, classes, retreats and trainings in the areas of yoga and meditation, health, permaculture and a wide range of subjects related to building sustainable and harmonious communities. It can accommodate up to 60 people indoors and up to a few hundred during the warmer months when camping is possible.  Ananda Gaorii also has a commercial organic bakery which delivers bread and cakes to Copenhagen and the local area. 

The objectives of the project are 1) To provide long term residents and participants (including the EVS volunteers) with non-formal learning experiences that will strengthen their community living skills, deepen their personal growth, give them tools to improve their physical and mental health, broaden their vision and give them an opportunity to learn the values and competencies related to living sustainably and managing an active project; 2) To offer short term learning experiences to those who attend the classes, retreats, workshops and trainings offered at Ananda Gaorii or who simply visit Ananda Gaorii to see what we are doing. 3) To benefit the local community by organizing activities which help support and integrate refugees and build a more resilient community;  4) To strengthen our engagement  and cooperation with other organizations sharing similar goals. 5) To encourage volunteering. 

The activities of the project include: planning and organizing the daily life of the community; learning and practicing yoga and meditation including an option to learn how to teach basic yoga classes; building, maintenance, renovation and interior design; growing food; developing systems for recycling and efficient use of resources; creating small projects for generating income or improving the daily life of the community; hosting and promoting workshops, retreats and classes; looking after the project's website and social media; guiding and coordinating short term volunteers; engaging refugees in cultural and learning activities; participating in farmer's markets and other local activities; exploring the local region; music and learning evenings; swimming at the beach. Between ten to twenty short and long term volunteers are normally present on the project so the duties and responsibilities will be shared amongst all according to individual abilities, interests and the needs of the moment. 

Six volunteers have been selected with skills and talents matching the activities of the project, with good prior experience in local volunteering,  and who showed a great deal of enthusiasm for the lifestyle and values of the project. 

The methodology used in carrying out the project is non-formal education - a combination of full immersion in a community lifestyle; learning by doing; personal research; mentoring and some participation in classes and workshops. 

The main results and impacts we envisage are happier, more confident, more aware and more capable young people playing active and useful roles in creating more harmonious and sustainable communities.  We also envisage our own organization and our partner organizations acquiring new competencies and being able to do better work through cooperation and mutual learning. Finally we envisage a more aware, resilient and harmonious local community in which refugees feel more welcome and feel they have more opportunities for establishing themselves successfully in the area. The potential long term benefits are a healthier, happier and more sustainable world.

EVS project “Let’s Do It Volunteer 2” involves 7 hosting activities – 4 in Estonia and 3 in abroad (Italy, Portugal and Macedonia).

Project includes 7 volunteers from 4 different sending organizations going to different 7 hosting organisations with 6 countries (Estonia, France, United Kingdom, Macedonia, Portugal and Italy) involved. There are 7 hosting organizations and 4 sending organizations and 1 coordinator organisation involved in the project. 

All the activities are long term ones. Duration of the activities is 6 months in Italy, 12 months in Portugal and Macedonia, and 8, 9, 11 and 12 months in Estonia. 

Two main themes of the current EVS project are Environmental and climate change, international cooperation. and Youth. The aim of the EVS project is to enable the volunteer to develop him/herself by giving him an international experience and to support the collaboration between the sending, hosting organisation and coordinator of this European Voluntary Service project. 

Creating a working environment where the partners can develop new actions and the volunteers’ new knowledge, skills and attitudes. During the project there are different activities with different target groups implemented: working with global partners and youth; working in NGO with international youth projects, developing activities in local community etc. 

Throughout the project different non formal education methods are used. All background learn in the past years of cooperation among most of those organisations will be implemented and developed.
Sustainable Future Food Systems through Youth Participation

Agriculture is the backbone of the European society and an important driver for sustainable, regional development which is reflected in the big share of the European budget. With our project “Sustainable Future Food Systems through Youth Participation” we want to bring together and encourage young people from different parts of Europe to engage in the field of sustainable agricultural systems. Besides a focus on environmental topics, the volunteers get to know the EU institutions from inside, policy making processes and furthermore, experience the importance of being an active citizen within the European community. Five volunteers from Finland, Portugal, the UK, Germany and Turkey will get insights about how an NGO is working, learn about the different units (project management, policy, research, communications, events) and learn in a more informal way when conducting an own project together. A basic interest in environmental topics is the only requirement that we expect from the volunteers. We encourage them to go to workshops, discussions or talks in other environmental NGOs and European institutions, however the scope is up to the volunteers themselves, according to the area and their interest. We want to provide a fruitful learning environment and a basic framework where the volunteers can get involved in an area that is of interest to them as a mean to empower them. A stay of 1-2 week(s) on an organic farm in Belgium gives the volunteers the opportunity to get to know the practical side of organic agriculture by being actively involved in farm work and in a rural Belgian community. 

The volunteers will gain a broader overview of the (organic) agricultural movement, enhancing at the same time their language and practical skills and their personal awareness of European Institutions’ role. Volunteers will be part of a dynamic, multicultural team, and supported by experienced office staff. They will receive individual and team tasks, with a constant supervision, assistance and final evaluation. As a group of five volunteers from very different parts of Europe, they will learn how to work together synchronizing their activities and overcoming possible language and cultural barriers.

We are convinced that the volunteers will find the knowledge and skills gained during their stay at IFOAM EU useful for their future and might get engaged in the field of sustainable agriculture or environmental issues, and can raise awareness among other young people about the importance of these issues. With the close relations to the European institutions we furthermore aim to raise awareness for the importance of a solidary and unified Europe. We expect that both through the promotion of the project through IFOAM EU and its network, the sending organisations and the volunteers, more young people will be interested in joining the EVS programme and new possibilities of cooperation can arise for all involved organisations.

Context 
The project is intended to spark a conversation between volunteers, entrepreneurs, NGO leaders, community members and business owners about who they are, where they are going and how their actions can have a greater, greener impact.
We attempt at achieving “Transforming Our World” by promoting leadership through entrepreneurship and by bringing communities’ voice into the city’s sustainable development plan, targeting goal 11. Sustainable cities & communities and goal 12. Responsible consumption & production, from United Nation’s Sustainable Development Agenda adopted in 2015. 

Objectives
To promote sustainable & responsible living across numerous environmental issues including food, fashion & events by engaging participants & community members in sustainable activities.
To support creative thinking about tackling changing trends in green businesses, introduce the fundamentals of kickstarting a social venture and develop their leadership potential.
To promote the idea of “thinking globally and acting locally” by giving people the sense of sustainability & community through informal education opportunities for young people which are high quality, sustainable and inclusive.
To support participants and communities to foster an understanding of mutual support & joint aid amongst individuals through teamwork and volunteering and to promote diversity & multicultural inclusion.

The EVS activity will meet these objectives by giving the 3 volunteers a structured 12 month placement in a sustainable community setting, gradually developing their skills through ‘on the job’ training within the two key pillars of Regather’s entrepreneurial activities: food and events, while providing opportunities with a focus on individual needs and interests. The EVS will be structured in a non-restrictive manner, in order to provide volunteers with time to focus on individual tasks or personal projects regarding sustainable development, community needs, their own learning plan, cultural expression. They are meant to encourage creativity & initiative and will be adapted. 

The Youth Exchange will give 25 young people from 5 countries, the opportunity to meet through team challenges, creative brainstorming & crafty events, with interaction and involvement in the management of the exchange by the three EVS volunteers. In order to deepen their knowledge and interest in ecological & sustainable development, the project will incorporate study visits, awareness workshops on environmental degradation, waste challenges & pioneering solutions, social cohesion oriented games and energisers. Active participation, group and team work & learning by doing will form the methodological foundation of the exchange. The whole activity is perceived as a mutual exchange of learning situations based on participants’ experiences and opinions.

Results and impact
EVS participants will increase their experience, skills and competences in sustainable development and learn how to make entrepreneurial decisions and deliver social impact for the local community. We also expect that they will have explored future career paths and to have considered social entrepreneurship, sustainable events management and not-for-profit organisations as a viable and rewarding career path. All of the participants will be able of recognising the interconnection between the impact of our collective choices & how they can affect the environment and people. They will increase their confidence in communication (especially in English), teamwork and leadership. They will have increased their international connections and their sense of belonging to a European community and network that can support them to achieve their goals.

By the end of the project we see the EVS “team” formed of determined, self-sufficient individuals who are confident, expressive and integrated into the community in Sheffield and whose impact will outlive the duration of the project.
The long term benefits of this project will be to strengthen links with the volunteers, participants, social enterprises, NGO leaders, local community and people who actively engage in the city’s sustainable development plan and work together to make a difference, locally, internationally, globally.
We also want to ensure the creation of a network of organisations that share the same principles and act in the spirit of European values. We will work to maintain good partnerships that meet each other’s needs and we hope to strengthen them by establishing solidarity projects involving sustainable development between participating countries that will continue beyond this project. Collaboration and partnerships ensure trusting and lasting relationships that will create a stronger and greener community.
